executive_summary: Positive trends in demand variables and near-constant demand from poultry processors, along with a recovery in the price of poultry meat in 2021 and 2022, have led to rising industry revenue over the five years to 2024. Additionally, increased demand for chicken as a substitute for other meats, particularly red meat, helped limit revenue declines amid the COVID-19 pandemic. In addition, increasing health consciousness among US consumers has boosted consumption of white meat in general. A rising price of feed from a low prior to the period has also driven growth. Higher feed and poultry prices have aided industry profit as rising purchase costs have been passed along to customers. Moving forward, industry conditions will remain relatively consistent. Per capita poultry consumption will continue to rise, albeit at a slower rate.

current_performance.current_performance_point_title: Steady demand even amid the COVID-19 pandemic
current_performance.current_performance_point_description: While the COVID-19 pandemic led to many restaurants shutting down, consumers' overall demand for poultry meat remained steady, allowing for a swift recovery from the pandemic.
The price of poultry has risen in recent years, ultimately leading industry revenue to climb strongly, even as demand has been steady.

Chicken production has historically been vulnerable to disruptions from disease outbreaks, severe weather and distribution issues; rising imports, particularly from Chile and Canada, have offset lower domestic production.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Falling feed prices help reduce volatility
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: The stabilization of feed prices over the next five years is forecast to substantially boost poultry farms' bottom lines. Lower production costs equate to higher profit, a favorable prospect for industry stakeholders.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Poultry exports are poised for growth
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: As the trade deficit shrinks in the coming years, attributable to a depreciating US dollar and recouping domestic consumption, poultry farms stand to benefit. Fewer imports mean local poultry farms can enhance their market shares and enjoy better profitability.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_title: Healthier diets lead to more poultry consumption
future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the next five years, consumers will continue to move towards healthier diets. Poultry, particularly chicken and turkey, are less fatty and lower in cholesterol than red meats like beef and pork. As consumers increasingly choose nutrition-dense foods, this will lead to an amplified demand for poultry products.
Rising demand for organic chicken, reflecting consumers' wariness of processed food diets, emphasizes the need for poultry farms to adapt their rearing procedures and sustainability practices.

industry_definition: This industry includes farms that raise chickens and turkeys for meat production. Downstream meat processors and food producers supply farmers with chicks, feed and payment, according to contractual agreements. Farmers provide growing facilities, animal care and agricultural expertise. Revenue is recorded in the final prices that farmers receive per average weight of a live animal. This industry excludes chicken egg production, poultry hatcheries and other poultry production.
key_trends: Price points can differentiate poultry products. Farmers that successfully manage operating costs can offer competitive market prices. Retailers typically enter into supply contracts with large operators that offer low, competitive prices.
Large chicken and turkey farming operations benefit from economies of scale. Larger companies also generally have long-standing supply contracts, securing their position in the market.

Demand for chicken and turkey meat has remained steady. Even during the COVID-19 pandemic, consumers sought the same amount of poultry but from different sources. Although some prices rose, overall demand did not waver.

Rising prices have boosted farmers' revenue. Poultry prices have increased partly because farmers are dealing with higher costs. Demand for chicken and turkey meat remains steady despite these price hikes.

Tyson Foods leads the chicken and turkey farming industry. The Arkansas-based company has a robust network of poultry farms. Many farms are small, independent operations. These farms may organize into cooperatives to have greater market power.
Volatile production leads to volatile revenue. Animal health issues, feed costs, demand for substitute meats and weather patterns all contribute to uncertainty for farmers.
Poultry farmers are regulated on a federal, state and local level. On the federal level, the USDA and the FDA regulate the industry.

market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes poultry processors, which are downstream from large companies known as integrators, who account for virtually the entire market for poultry farmers. Deboning for further processing forms a crucial component for poultry producers. Historically, chickens were overwhelmingly marketed whole, but the emergence of large, capital-intensive farming operations has increased processing capabilities along with consumer demand for ready-to-cook boneless chicken products.

market_segmentation.segment: Fast food and commercial food services
market_segmentation.segment_description: This segment includes fast food and commercial food services, which are downstream from large companies known as integrators, who account for virtually the entire market for poultry farmers. The COVID-19 pandemic forced many restaurants to close, resulting in limited demand from food service establishments. However, most fast food establishments were able to seamlessly transition to delivery and to-go service, and those who couldn't have since reopened.

This segment includes grocery stores which are downstream from large companies known as integrators, who account for virtually the entire market for poultry farmers. Grocery stores and institutional demand from schools, hospitals and government are key markets for some players. While most downstream markets prefer processed meat, butchers, ethnic grocery stores and specialty restaurants purchase live birds for the freshest possible products.
This segment includes other markets which are downstream from large companies known as integrators, who account for virtually the entire market for poultry farmers.

products_and_services.product_description: This segment includes broilers, the birds predominantly raised for meat in the United States. Unlike other chickens, broilers are raised specifically for meat rather than for their eggs or breeding qualities. Broilers are genetically selected for fast growth and are typically slaughtered after reaching two and a half pounds, usually within six to seven weeks. Commercial broilers are specially bred for large-scale, intensive production and grow much faster than egg-laying or dual-purpose breeds.

This segment includes broilers, the birds predominantly raised for meat in the United States. Unlike other chickens, broilers are raised specifically for meat rather than for their eggs or breeding qualities.

This segment accounts for the production of turkey products, of which the United States is the world's largest producer and exporter. The majority of turkey meat exports ship as lower-value turkey parts or ground or mechanically deboned meat. While exports are a major part of the US turkey market, domestic consumption is higher than in any other country. A perception of turkey as a healthier alternative to other meats is the source of much of this segment's demand on days other than Thanksgiving;

This segment includes organic poultry. Organic chicken dominates this segment because of its relatively short production cycle, lower price and integrated production. Organic poultry meat certified under the US Department of Agriculture's National Organic Program comes from animals raised according to certain guidelines. The trend toward organic poultry has stemmed from rising consumer concerns about food safety and animal welfare.

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Poultry has historically benefited from the perception that it has lower fat content than other meats, which has helped to increase the consumption of chicken and turkey. An increase in per capita poultry consumption positively affects industry demand.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Chile has grown to be the industry's leading source of imports
international_trade_points.trade_description: Poultry imports from Chile have grown in recent years as domestic poultry production has faltered and the US dollar has appreciated. However, this

international_trade_points.trade_title: Other imports come from Canada and Mexico
international_trade_points.trade_description: Besides Chile, the remaining poultry imports to the US come from North America, thanks to proximity and existing trade agreements. With a strong domestic supply of poultry, importing chicken and turkey meat from other countries often isn't worth the shipping costs.

international_trade_points.trade_title: The US is a leading and growing poultry exporter, particularly to China
international_trade_points.trade_description: The US is the second largest poultry exporter in the world, behind only Brazil. The Chinese market exhibits high demand for American chicken paws, which are unusually large and have virtually no other market.

international_trade_points.trade_title: Canada and Mexico are major export destinations
international_trade_points.trade_description: After China, Mexico and Canada are the second and third leading destinations for US poultry exports thanks to proximity and existing trade agreements.

business_locations.location_description: Most of the nation's poultry farms are located in the southeast, with Arkansas leading the region. The southeast's favorable climate, relatively cheap land and labor costs and a historical shift from cotton farming to poultry in the 1940s and 1950s have contributed to this concentration.

The plains region is home to the second most poultry farmers in the US. Proximity to poultry processing facilities enhances logistical efficiency, reducing transportation time and costs for farmers. The area's extensive agricultural infrastructure supports poultry and feed production, making it a viable and attractive location for poultry farming operations.
The great lakes region has the third most poultry farms in the US.
There are at least a few poultry farms in every region of the country. The chicken and turkey farming industry is mainly made up of small farms.

regulations_points.regulation_description: The FDA and the USDA's Food Safety Inspection Service (FSIS) regulate poultry farms. These agencies set legal limits for poultry products' antibiotics and other drug residues. The USDA's Animal and Plant Health Inspection Service ensures the health of poultry breeding stock. These regulations help maintain food safety and public health standards.

Concentrated Animal-Feeding Operations (CAFOs) must apply for permits to discharge pollutants. CAFOs in the poultry industry are defined by size, manure handling systems, or pollution levels. This regulation ensures that environmental impacts are managed.

regulations_points.regulation_title: Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act
regulations_points.regulation_description: Poultry farms must adhere to stringent disposal regulations for dead chickens, including using disposal pits, composting, incineration, rendering and acid fermentation. Disposal must occur within 12 hours of death, with permits required from a local veterinarian. Compliance with the Hazard Analysis and Critical Control Point program and the Public Health Security and Bioterrorism Preparedness and Response Act of 2002 ensures biosecurity and public health.

barriers_points.barrier_description: Poultry farmers face numerous health, safety and environmental regulations at the federal, state and local levels. Navigating these regulations can be challenging for new entrants, necessitating comprehensive compliance to establish and maintain operations.

Poultry farms require significant infrastructure; most are family enterprises passed down from generation to generation. Some farms do manage to launch successful grow operations through the takeover of a struggling farm that already has grow houses.
Commercial poultry production is highly competitive due to many small operations vying for bonuses under contracts with the same integrator. One key differentiation strategy is specialization.

Although most farmers own their land, those who rent will have more difficulty increasing their profit in an already competitive business. The grow houses themselves and the systems that go into each house pose a formidable investment.

basis_points.basis_description: Price points can differentiate poultry products. Farmers that successfully manage operating costs can offer competitive market prices.
Large chicken and turkey farming operations benefit from economies of scale. Larger companies also generally have long-standing supply contracts, securing their position in the market.

concentration_points.concentration_description: There are a few large, vertically integrated companies in the chicken and turkey farming industry. The industry's largest player is Tyson foods, which has extensive farming and meat processing facilities in the US.

Small farms, often passed down through generations, are still the most common type of establishment in the industry. Smaller farmers can form cooperatives in order to have greater market power when selling their products.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Animal Feed Price Inflation Pushes Up Purchase Costs
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Animal feed costs account for a substantial share of revenue as chicken and turkey feed is vital for boosting poultry carcass weight and expanding poultry production capacity. Feed costs surged following the pandemic as supply chain disruptions made it difficult for crop farmers to bring their goods to market, creating a shortage of field crops typically used for animal feed.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Although most farmers own their land, those who rent will have more difficulty increasing their profit in an already competitive business. The grow houses themselves and the systems that go into each house pose a formidable investment.

volatility_points.volatility_description: Animal health issues, spikes in feed costs and weather patterns affect production. Although fee arrangements between integrators and growers vary from contract to contract, poultry farmers' revenue largely depends on the weight of live birds produced.

Shifts in prices for alternative meats and other sources of protein can also cause revenue fluctuations. A rise in the price of beef will increase consumer demand for poultry, increasing poultry production.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Rising Automation Investment is Reducing Wage Costs
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Productivity competition has increased since a shortage of workers following the COVID-19 pandemic. The key to attaining the best possible control of the production process in modern poultry farming is automating and monitoring your barn processes via 24-hour automation systems.

technological_change_points.technological_change_title: Farms See Opportunities with Other Rearing Methods
technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Farmers could change how they raise their birds for advertising and health purposes. As consumers have become more concerned with animal welfare, demand for cage-free and pasture-raised chicken has grown.

FAQs.question: How do you manage your relationships with customers in the grocery and food manufacturing industries?
FAQs.answer: Downstream industries are crucial for livestock production industries.

FAQs.question: Does your farm export any livestock or face competition from imports?
FAQs.answer: Meat industries are not typically impacted by trade.

FAQs.question: How has your business responded to the increased threat of severe weather?
FAQs.answer: Severe weather can result in fluctuations in the price of feed.

FAQs.question: Are you located close to the rail and road networks used to ship your livestock?
FAQs.answer: Distribution costs can be significant. Locating close to transportation systems can help reduce costs.

FAQs.question: Does your farm use any genetically modified feed products or hormones used to stimulate growth?
FAQs.answer: Some farms use feed produced with GMO seeds.

FAQs.question: Have you explored to possibility of using automated feeders or cleaning equipment?
FAQs.answer: Poultry farms can invest in feeders and other technology to increase automation.

FAQs.question: Do you receive any federal subsidies? How much of your revenue do they comprise?
FAQs.answer: Federal subsidies benefit farms when poultry prices drop.

FAQs.question: Do you work with trade associations or other interest groups to advance your company's interests?
FAQs.answer: Some farms form cooperatives to share resources and increase profit.

FAQs.question: What trends impact your profitability?
FAQs.answer: Poultry profit is determined by feed and poultry prices.

FAQs.question: Do contract customers reevaluate their needs during times of economic uncertainty?
FAQs.answer: Many poultry farms operate under contracts with meat processors.

FAQs.question: Do you have contracts in place with manufacturers? How can these relationships be strengthened?
FAQs.answer: Almost all poultry farmers depend on contracts with poultry processors. Contracts help ensure all output is sold and provide farmers with production and technical support. Long-term supply contracts increase the likelihood that farmers will profit.

FAQs.question: What financial management systems do you have in place? Are you able to manage debt effectively?
FAQs.answer: Debt and related financing are essential to a farm's success. Farms that manage debt well during low demand will likely stay in business.

FAQs.question: Are you located near any major processors? What domestic and international markets are you looking to break into?
FAQs.answer: Most poultry farms in the United States are located in or near the Southeast region. This is because most major processors are headquartered in this area and a shorter distance to these downstream markets reduces transportation costs.

FAQs.question: How have fluctuations in the price of poultry meat affected your company in the past? How do you support revenue when prices dip?
FAQs.answer: A rise in the domestic price of poultry can increase per-unit returns and expand chicken production. Increases in price result in lower sales and revenue, but price decreases can also result in lower revenue.

FAQs.question: How volatile are feed stock prices? What percentage of your revenue goes toward grain purchases?
FAQs.answer: Feed is the primary input for poultry farming, so its price substantially affects industry costs. Industry farmers will likely pass the feed cost onto customers through higher meat prices, raising revenue.
